properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Substantial high-elevation snowfall expected. Snow will continue over western Newfoundland today and Wednesday, and will become heavy at times over elevated terrain. Accumulations are forecast to reach 20 to 30 cm along the highest parts of the Viking Trail between Wiltondale and Bonne Bay, while totals around 50 cm are likely across higher parts of the Long Range Mountains. The snow will begin to ease Wednesday night. Snowfall amounts in coastal communities will be much lower, with as little as 5 cm in some locations near sea level. Anyone considering using back-country trails or high-elevation roads should be aware of the large contrast in conditions. These routes may become difficult to navigate due to the accumulating snow. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-05-01T05:15:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T13:16:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3537489101.2019
Area: Gros Morne, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of snow and ice pellets beginning Wednesday morning changing to rain or freezing rain Wednesday afternoon. Precipitation will begin as snow and ice pellets Wednesday morning. Snow and ice pellet amounts of 2 to 5 cm are possible before the precipitation changes to rain Wednesday afternoon. However, with temperatures expected to remain near the zero degree mark there is the risk of freezing rain Wednesday afternoon. There is also uncertainty as to how much precipitation will fall as rain or freezing rain. Current indications are that rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm are possible by Thursday morning. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. This precipitation is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T09:33:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-05-01T01:34:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3728199312.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts of 30 to 45 mm tonight through Wednesday night. Rain is expected to begin tonight and continue Wednesday and Wednesday night. Rain may be heavy at times. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 45 mm are expected by Thursday morning. Locally higher amounts are possible. Rainfall warnings may be issued if the warning criteria of 50 mm or more is expected in 24 hours or less. This rainfall is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Continues For The Red River From Emerson To The Red River Floodway Channel Inlet
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre continues to issue a Flood Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-05-01T09:45:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-30T09:50:15-05:00, 0CA7A2F7-E0DE-CF4D-F859-0D2F718EC87F
Area: Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts of 20 to 35 mm are expected Wednesday and Wednesday night. Rain is expected begin overnight or early Wednesday morning and will continue Wednesday night. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 35 mm are forecast by Thursday morning. Locally higher amounts are possible. The ground has limited ability to absorb further rainfall. Flood messaging is in effect for much of Central and Eastern Ontario. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. This rainfall is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T09:43:54-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, snow or freezing precipitation on Wednesday ... A low pressure system will cross the Great Lakes on Wednesday, bringing mixed precipitation to the Outaouais. Precipitation will begin mainly as rain midday Wednesday before changing over to snow over areas further north in the afternoon. The snow may change over to freezing rain Thursday night. Rainfall amounts could approach 25 millimetres along the Ottawa River, while areas further north would receive 5 centimetres of wet, heavy snow. Significant ice accretion is also possible before precipitation comes to an end Thursday morning. Rain possibly heavy could contribute to rising water levels. The wet, heavy snow and the freezing precipitation could cause driving conditions to deteriorate and put significant weight on trees and power lines. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T10:51:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-05-01T02:52:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2224618560.2019
Area: Rapides-des-Joachims area, Fort William - Shawville area, Low - Wakefield area, Maniwaki - Gracefield area, Papineauville - Chénéville area, Papineau-Labelle Reserve area, Lièvre River area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and freezing rain possible Wednesday evening... A low pressure system will track across the Great Lakes on Wednesday bringing a mixed bag of precipitation to the Laurentians. Precipitation will begin as as snow on Wednesday in the late afternoon or early evening before changing over to freezing rain or rain toward midnight. Local accumulations of wet, heavy snow approaching 5 centimetres are expected Wednesday evening, especially over higher elevations. Significant ice accretion is also possible in some areas before precipitation comes to an end Thursday morning. Travel may be difficult due to snow and freezing precipitation. The weight of the snow and ice may impact trees and power lines. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T10:51:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-05-01T02:52:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2406521387.2019
Area: Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Adèle - Saint-Sauveur area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Minimum temperatures will fall to or slightly below the freezing mark overnight tonight. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T18:38:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-05-01T02:39:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3750986417.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected Wednesday afternoon and evening. Precipitation will begin as snow and ice pellets Wednesday morning. Snow and ice pellet amounts of 2 to 5 cm are possible before the precipitation changes to freezing rain Wednesday afternoon. Freezing rain will last for several hours before changing to rain Wednesday night. This wintry precipitation is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T11:58:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-05-01T02:59:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3112552651.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 40 mm are expected Wednesday and Wednesday night. Precipitation will begin overnight as snow or ice pellets. Local snow and ice pellet amounts of 2 cm are possible before the precipitation changes to rain Wednesday morning. Rain will be heavy at times and continue Wednesday night. Total rainfall amounts of 25 to 40 mm are possible by Thursday morning. Flood messaging is in effect for much of Central Ontario. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. This rainfall is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T11:19:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T19:20:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2923721880.2019
Area: Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst, Haliburton - Minden - Southern Haliburton County

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For La Plonge Ir #192
properties.Summary:
Description: A precautionary drinking water advisory has been issued for La Plonge IR #192. This advisory is for the residents of La Plonge Reserve and for any individuals who may access water from the La Plonge Reserve system. This advisory will be in effect until May 7, 2019.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow will develop this evening in the Norman Wells region as an intense weather system moves in from the Beaufort Sea. The heavy snow will continue through Wednesday and Thursday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by the time the snow ends. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
